title: Conclusion for test of cinnamon on blood glucose

content.description: A group of <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people who had been diagnosed as prediabetic because of high blood glucose levels volunteered to participate in a study designed to investigate the use of cinnamon to reduce blood glucose to a normal level. Of the <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>80</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> people, <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> were randomly assigned to take a cinnamon tablet each day and the other <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> were assigned to take a placebo each day. The people did not know which tablet they were taking. Their blood glucose levels were measured at the end of one month. The results showed that <math alttext="14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people in the cinnamon group and <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people in the placebo group had normal blood glucose levels.
content.question: For people similar to those in the study, do the data provide convincing statistical evidence that the proportion who would be classified as normal after one month of taking cinnamon is greater than the proportion who would be classified as normal after one month of not taking cinnamon?

choices.label: No conclusion can be made about the use of cinnamon because the people in the study were volunteers.
There is convincing statistical evidence at the level of <math alttext="0.01" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

There is convincing statistical evidence at the level of <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> but not at the level of <math alttext="0.01" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

There is convincing statistical evidence at the level of <math alttext="0.10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> but not at the level of <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
There is not convincing statistical evidence at any reasonable significance level.

content.answer: There is not convincing statistical evidence at any reasonable significance level.
